title: 113_hr5611
content: The Act is titled the "Public School Emergency Relief Act" and includes findings. The "Public School Emergency Relief Act" acknowledges the unprecedented influx of unaccompanied alien children in 2014, leading to a strain on the public school system. The Act creates an emergency grant for the 2014-2015 school year to address this issue. An emergency grant for the 2014-2015 school year is provided to local educational agencies affected by enrollment increases due to unaccompanied alien children. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY EMERGENCY IMPACT AID FOR IMMIGRANT STUDENTS. Temporary Emergency Impact Aid Authorized for State and Local Educational Agencies and BIA-funded Schools to provide instruction for students. The Secretary of Education must publish a notice of funds availability within 14 days of the Act's enactment. State educational agencies seeking emergency impact aid must submit an application within 7 days, including information on immigrant student counts. BIA-funded schools and local educational agencies must submit an application for emergency impact aid within 14 days of the notice publication, including immigrant student enrollment data. The eligible BIA-funded schools and local educational agencies must provide immigrant student enrollment data for each quarter to determine the number of immigrant students served. The amount of emergency impact aid for the 2014-2015 school year is based on the increase in the number of immigrant students enrolled in eligible local educational agencies and BIA-funded schools in the State. The Secretary of Education will reduce emergency impact aid if funds are insufficient to cover the full amount a State educational agency is eligible for. State agencies that have already made payments to local educational agencies may retain their share. State educational agencies may retain a portion of payments to cover additional costs for enrolling immigrant students in local schools. State educational agencies must provide quarterly emergency impact aid payments for the 2014-2015 school year based on the number of immigrant students. Each payment will be 25 percent of the total amount determined. The Secretary of Education will establish a timeline for these payments. The State educational agency will establish a timeline for quarterly reporting on the number of immigrant students to ensure timely disbursements. If funds are insufficient, payments to eligible local educational agencies or BIA-funded schools will be reduced proportionally. Eligible local educational agencies or BIA-funded schools must use emergency impact aid payments to provide services to elementary and secondary schools enrolling immigrant students. Authorized uses of funds include personnel compensation, acquiring curricular materials, and providing basic instructional services. The emergency impact aid payments must be used by eligible local educational agencies or BIA-funded schools to provide services to immigrant students, including tutoring, transportation, health services, counseling, and other support services. For immigrant students with disabilities, the payments should be used for special education and related services in accordance with the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) defines terms like "child with a disability", "special education", and "related services". Eligible local educational agencies or BIA-funded schools must return any unused emergency impact aid payments to the State educational agency. Eligible local educational agencies or schools must return any unused emergency impact aid payments to the State educational agency by the end of the 2014-2015 school year. State educational agencies receiving aid must also return any unobligated funds. Aid and payments provided under this section are limited to expenses incurred during the 2014-2015 school year. The State educational agency and eligible local educational agencies or BIA-funded schools receiving emergency impact aid have limits on administrative expenses. The funding calculation under section 8003 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act excludes immigrant students receiving emergency impact aid. The Act prohibits discrimination against immigrant students based on various factors such as race, color, national origin, religion, disability, or sex. It also clarifies that the Act does not alter the provisions of other relevant laws like the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act and the Civil Rights Act. The Act prohibits discrimination against immigrant students based on various factors. Payments under this section for immigrant students are not considered as income for tax purposes. State aid eligibility for local educational agencies is not affected by emergency impact aid payments received. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The terms used in this Act are defined based on the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions for eligible local educational agency, eligible BIA-funded school, and immigrant student.
